title: Feasts of the LORD
shortSummary: Leviticus 23 outlines the appointed feasts and holy convocations that the LORD commanded Israel to observe throughout the year. These sacred festivals, including the Sabbath, Passover, Pentecost, Trumpets, Day of Atonement, and Tabernacles, serve as divine appointments for worship, remembrance, and atonement, reflecting God's covenant relationship with His people.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet through whom God communicated the laws and instructions for Israel, including the feasts.

keyCharacters.name: The Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: God's chosen people who are instructed to observe the feasts as holy convocations and statutes throughout their generations.

keyCharacters.name: The Priest
keyCharacters.description: The religious officiant who performs the wave offerings and sacrifices during the feasts, acting as mediator between God and Israel.

definitions.definition: A sacred assembly or gathering called by God for worship and rest, during which no servile work is to be done.
A ritual act where the priest waves a sheaf or offering before the LORD as a symbol of dedication and acceptance.
A weekly day of rest and worship commanded by God, symbolizing His rest after creation and Israel's covenant relationship.
The act of making reconciliation for sin, particularly emphasized on the Day of Atonement as a solemn occasion for repentance and cleansing.

outline.heading: Introduction to the Feasts and Sabbath
outline.description: God commands Moses to instruct Israel regarding the LORD’s appointed feasts, beginning with the weekly Sabbath as a holy convocation and day of rest.

outline.heading: Passover and Feast of Unleavened Bread
outline.description: Instructions for observing the Passover on the 14th day of the first month and the seven-day Feast of Unleavened Bread, including holy convocations on the first and seventh days.

outline.heading: Feast of Firstfruits and Counting to Pentecost
outline.description: God commands the offering of the wave sheaf and the counting of seven Sabbaths leading to Pentecost, with detailed offerings and instructions to leave gleanings for the poor.

outline.heading: Feast of Trumpets and Day of Atonement
outline.description: The seventh month begins with the Feast of Trumpets, a day of rest and holy convocation, followed by the solemn Day of Atonement, a day for afflicting the soul and making atonement for sin.

outline.heading: Feast of Tabernacles and Conclusion
outline.description: The seven-day Feast of Tabernacles is established as a time to dwell in booths and rejoice before the LORD, commemorating Israel’s wilderness dwelling and God’s provision.

application: Observe the Sabbath as a holy day of rest and worship, honoring God’s design for physical and spiritual renewal.
Celebrate God’s redemptive work by remembering Christ as our Passover Lamb through the feasts, especially Passover and Pentecost.
Approach God with reverence and repentance, especially on solemn occasions like the Day of Atonement, cultivating a heart of humility and confession.
Rejoice in God’s provision and faithfulness, as exemplified in the Feast of Tabernacles, by expressing gratitude and dwelling in His presence daily.

keyVerses.text: Six days shall work be done: but the seventh day is the sabbath of rest, an holy convocation; ye shall do no work therein: it is the sabbath of the LORD in all your dwellings.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the Sabbath as a perpetual holy day of rest and worship, foundational for Israel’s covenant life.

keyVerses.text: In the fourteenth day of the first month at even is the LORD'S passover.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the beginning of the sacred feasts with the Passover, commemorating God’s deliverance of Israel from Egypt.

keyVerses.text: Also on the tenth day of this seventh month there shall be a day of atonement: it shall be an holy convocation unto you; and ye shall afflict your souls, and offer an offering made by fire unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the solemn Day of Atonement as a critical time for repentance and reconciliation with God.

keyVerses.text: Ye shall dwell in booths seven days; all that are Israelites born shall dwell in booths:
keyVerses.significance: This verse commands the Feast of Tabernacles, reminding Israel of God’s provision and their dependence on Him.
